metadata.title: Synergy effect of carbon nano-fillers on the fracture toughness of structural composites

sections.text:
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
*corresponding author, e-mail: kostopoulos@mech.upatras.gr
The present study focuses on the development of carbon fiber reinforced polymers (CFRPs) with nanomodified matrix composed of two different carbon based nano-fillers, few layered Graphene NanoPlatelets (GNPs) and Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotubes (MWCNTs). The main purpose is to increase the interlaminar fracture toughness of CFRPs, by exploiting the synergistic effect between nano-fillers. Hybrid doped CFRPs were prepared in the first case by combining0.5%wt. GNPs and 0.5%wt. MWCNTs while in the second by 0.5%wt. GNPs and 1%wt. MWCNTs. Mode I fracture toughness (GIC)was enhanced up to 45% in the second hybrid whereas composites with GNPs or MWCNTs at equal amounts exhibited 27% and 31% increase respectively. Mode II results reported the second hybrid with the highest increase of GIIC up to 25%, while individually the same contents achieved 18% and 13% increase. Finally, Scanning Electron Microscopy confirmed the synergistic associated mechanisms of hybrids compared to the reference material.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Fiber reinforced polymers (FRP) are composites that are mainly used in advanced engineering structures. Their usage ranges in different areas including aerospace, automobile, sports and military industries. The key factor for the increasing demand of the composites in recent years is their higher specific strength and stiffness compared to the conventional metals. However, poor out of plane properties are observed due to the absence of through the thickness reinforcement in order to sustain transverse loads. Additionally, the low polymer matrix toughness leads to interlaminar failure, such as delamination. In light of this issue, an entire new field of research has been conducted, which includes developments for high performance resin systems with the incorporation of nano-sized particles [1-7].The nano-phase induces the concept of multiscale reinforcements and introduces additional energy dissipation mechanics during fracture and thus contributes among others to the enhancement of the interlaminar fracture toughness of the composite.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT C. Kostagiannakopoulou, X. Tsilimigkra, G. Sotiriadis and V. Kostopoulos
Hence, the development of multi-scale composites leads to the enhancement of damage tolerance and multi-functionality of conventional CFRPs. The incorporated nano-sized fillers are usually selected according to the desired properties of the final composite. The most popular nano-materials toward this direction are the carbon nanotubes (CNTs) due to their outstanding mechanical, electrical and thermal properties. Furthermore, their high aspect ratio and specific surface area make them an ideal candidate for enhancing the properties of polymeric matrix and therefore the performance of CFRP composites [8-13]. Concerning the fracture behavior Kostopoulos et al. [8] presented an increase of 60 and 75% in GIC and GIIC respectively including 1%wt. MWCNTs into the epoxy matrix of composites. Yamamoto et al. [9] reported the significant increase of the flexural strength and the fracture toughness of a MWCNTs (0.5 and 1 % wt.) reinforced Al2O3 composite. In particular, the 0.5%wt. MWCNTs content was better enhanced the composite's flexural strength at a rate of 37% while the fracture toughness was increased up to 34% compared to the reference material. Zakaria et. al [14] also studied the mechanical properties of epoxy nanocomposite systems with MWCNTs as fillers at various loadings (0.5, 1 and 3 %wt.). The highest improvements were observed by the researchers when 1%wt. MWCNTs were integrated within the epoxy system. More precisely, the tensile and flexural strength of MWCNT nanocomposites were enhanced up to 26%, 29% respectively, compared to the neat epoxy The last few years, along with the CNTs investigation, graphite derivatives have attracted considerable attention from the research community. This is due to the fact that the derivatives of graphite combines the 2D layered structure of nanoclays with the superior mechanical, thermal and electrical properties of carbon nanotubes. Graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) are the most widely used graphite derivatives toward this direction. GNPs are disk-shaped graphite particles which are usually produced by the rapid heating of graphite intercalation compounds (GICs). The resulting material is composed of two or more layers of graphene planes with a platelet thickness ranges from 0.34 to 100nm. The last few years, researchers in this field have demonstrated that GNPs are very promising nano-fillers for enhancing the fracture properties of composites too. High improvements were observed by Zakaria et. al [14] when 1%wt. GNPs were integrated within the epoxy system. The tensile and flexural strength of GNP nanocomposites improved up to 26%, 29% respectively, compared to the neat epoxy. Bending and tensile performance of hand lay-up produced glass fabric/epoxy laminated composites were investigated by Seretis. et.al [15],
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
after matrix reinforcement with pre-dried graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) up to 30% wt. content. An almost linear increase of the flexural strength was observed by increasing the GNPs content until 5%. After this content, a “plateau” is being formed for GNPs contents ranging from 5% to 20%. Following the same trend tensile strength is being progressively increased until the value that corresponds to 5% w.t. GNPs, which was the maximum recorded. Further increase of the content was not beneficial for the material properties.Fracture properties were investigated by, Chandraserakan et al. [16] who reported that GIC increased by 25% with the integration of 0.5%wt. GNPs in nano-composites. Manov et al. [17] finally studied the impact properties of CFRPs and GFRP reinforced with TRGOs. 19% and 55% increase was achieved in CFRPs and GFRPs respectively in compression after impact (CAI) property with the addition of 0.3%wt TRGO into the epoxy matrix. The combination of 2D GNPs and 1DCNTs is a new research area where limited effort has been carried out, for investigating the effects of their simultaneous integration and possible synergistic effects in the epoxy system of a composite material. The idea of hybrid concepts is the production of hybrid nanocomposites not only by utilizing the advantages of each individual filler but also for a possible cooperation between them (synergistic effect) [18-25]. Yang et al. [18] reported the increase of 35.4% in tensile strength by incorporating 1%wt. (1:9) CD400-MWCNTs/MGNPs (Multi GrapheneNanoPlateletS) at the epoxy system. The same system exhibited higher thermal conductivity compared to the neat epoxy which reached 146.9 % increase. Kim et al. [19] investigated the effects of graphene/CNTs co reinforcement on mechanical properties of HDPE matrix nanocomposites. The tensile strength was significantly enhanced after adding 2.0 wt % of CNTs in GP-0.5/HDPE. Furthermore, towards the same direction L.Yue et.al. [20] prepared epoxy nanocomposites by dispersing the fillers CNT and GNP in the appropriate ratio in the epoxy resin. The sample of CNT0.8GNP0.2 showed significant improvement in both modulus and strength over the CNT and GNP single filler composites. Thus, a synergetic effect on flexural properties was achieved by the hybrid filler CNT0.8GNP0.2. In addition, Zhang et.al [21], composed mixed fillers of functionalized graphene (f-G) and functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (f-CNTs) (f-G-f-CNTs) and investigated their synergistic effects in terms of enhancing the tensile properties of poly (ether sulfone) (PES) composites. For the composite film with 5 wt% f- G-fCNTs (Wf-G/Wf-CNTs = 1:1), the modulus increased up to 97.8% and the tensile strength reached a 25.7% increase (relative to PES) with 1 wt% f-G-f-CNTs (Wf-G/Wf-CNTs = 1:1). Moreover, Y.T. Liu
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT C. Kostagiannakopoulou, X. Tsilimigkra, G. Sotiriadis and V. Kostopoulos
et.al [22], studied the incorporation of a Cu2+-coordinated MWCNT/GO (multiwall carbon nanotubes/graphene oxide) network in poly(styrene-co-butadiene-co-styrene) (SBS) which is one of the most widely used synthetic rubber. The Cu2+-coordinated MWCNT/GO(3/1) network endows the SBS matrix with the most profound reinforcing effect, i.e., a modulus increased up to 367% and 653% at a filler content of 0.25 wt% and 0.5 wt%, respectively. Li et al. [23] also presented synergistic effects for the different form of nano-reinforcements (MWCNTs and GNPs) with a total filler content of 2wt% in which the fracture toughness was increased by 57% compared to the neat epoxy. Yuanqing Li et.al [24] reported a remarkable synergetic effect between CNTs and GO sheets which improved the mechanical properties of the epoxy. The optimal tensile properties of CNT–GO/epoxy composites were achieved with 0.2 wt% GO and 0.04 wt% CNTs. The tensile strength and toughness of CNT–GO/epoxy were substantially improved compared to pure epoxy resin. Considerable remarks have also been reported by S. Chatterjee et.al. [25], who manufactured three sets of composite samples with (i) different concentrations of 5 µm GnP (ii) different concentrations of 25 µm GnP (iii) different ratios of CNT, GnP mixtures with a total of 0.5 wt.% nanofiller content. GnPs were dispersed in the epoxy resin using 3-roll mill calendaring. With a CNT:GnP ratio of 9:1 they recorded the highest improvement of 77% compared to the pristine epoxy samples .A better synergistic effect was observed for flexural modulus measurements where the composites with CNT:GnP ratio of 9:1 showed the highest increase of 17% compared to an increase of 9% and 5% with pure CNT and GnP respectively. The flexural modulus for the CNT:GnP ratio of 5:1 was also observed to be higher than that of composites with pure CNT and GnP. For fracture toughness, there was marked improvement with all ratios of nano-fillers. Researchers have also studied various hybrid concepts focused on nanomaterials. The effects of adding nanoclay (NC) or carbon nanotube (CNT), and a combination of both on bending, tensile strengths of nanocomposite plates were investigated by Tuzemen et al. [26]. The most significantly enhancement was observed at tensile strength of the hybrid concept (4%wt. NC and 0.3%wt. CNT) which increased 57% compared to the neat material. This increment was higher than the improvement provided by each filler individually, 47% for NC or 54% for CNT at the respective contents. Furthermore, in the direction of hybrid concepts, Kwon et. a [27] introduced the graphene/CNT hybrid as a multi-functional interfacial nano-reinforcement to enhance the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
mechanical properties of CFRP composites. The resulting hybrid-coated carbon fiber-reinforced composites showed an enhancement of over 10% in the short beam strength compared to un-coated carbon fiber composites It is conceivable that the cooperation of the different nano species affect positive the final properties of the composites as was detailed described above. Several researchers have confirmed the significantly increase in the electrical and thermal conductivity at hybrid nano composites. However, limited reports are referred to the further markedly contribution of the different fillers (CNTs/GNPs) at the fracture properties of CFRPs made out of resin nano-modified matrix by using hybrid, carbon based fillers. The aim of the present work is to explore new insights in the field of hybrid carbon based nano-modified epoxy matrices of CFRPs by exploiting the advantages of combining different nano-fillers which literature has proven their individual remarkable contribution. Hence, effort was undertaken for the development of modified carbon fiber reinforced composites (CFRP) integrated with MWCNTs and GNPs for enhancing the interlaminar fracture toughness of the final multi-scale reinforced composite. Mode I and mode II tests were performed and the fracture energy as a function of the type and the content of nano-material was concluded. Finally, toughening mechanisms of the nano-fillers were presented by the observation of the composites fracture surfaces with nano-reinforced matrices through scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The following sections present in detail the involved materials along with the manufacturing process, the experimental procedure where GIC and GIIC were calculated, SEM findings to confirm the toughening mechanisms and finally results and discussion to report the most important outcomes of the present work.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT C. Kostagiannakopoulou, X. Tsilimigkra, G. Sotiriadis and V. Kostopoulos

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text: The matrix material used in this study was a four part epoxy system provided by Huntsman Advanced Materials (Switzerland). This system consists of an epoxy resin (Araldite LY556), a hardener paste (Aradur 1571), an accelerator paste (Accelerator 1573) and a hardener based on polyamine (Hardener XB 3403) which, as recommended by the manufacturer, are typically mixed in the ratio of 100:23:5:12 by weight. The main reinforcement phase was a unidirectional carbon fabric, supplied by R&G (Germany), with an areal density of 140 g/m2.Regarding the nano-phase, the multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) produced by catalyzed chemical vapor deposition (CVD), were purchased from Arkema (France). MWCNTs were 98% pure with an average outer diameter of about 10-15nm, a length more than 500nm and a surface area of approximately 230m2/g. The graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs) were 97% pure and obtained from Cheap Tube Inc.(USA). GNPs consist of 20-25 graphene layers with an average thickness of 10-12nm and a typical diameter of 5 microns while their surface area was about 100m2/g. Table 1summarizes the aforementioned characteristics.

sections.heading: 2.2 Nano-reinforced matrix
sections.text:
The properties of polymer nanocomposites depend strongly on the dispersion of the nanofillers into the epoxy material. For a successful dispersion of GNPs and MWCNTs into the epoxy resin the following mixing procedure was employed: the selected contents of the filler in each case were incorporated in Araldite LY1556 epoxy resin. The mixture was subjected to a 3.5h high shear mixing (2.500 rpm) in a Dissolver Dispermat (ΑΕ, VMA Getzmann GmbH, Germany) in vacuum conditions in order to avoid the entrapped air during mixing process. This technique leads to the introduction of high shear forces and vortex flow in the nano-enhanced mixture during stirring which are responsible for the reduction of the agglomeration between nano-particles. Subsequently, the other parts of the system were added into the prepared mixture and placed in a vacuum chamber for degassing in order to eliminate air inclusion. Following the aforementioned process, six types of nano-reinforced mixtures with different proportions of CNTs/GNPs were developed and defined in Table 2.

US CR
IP T

ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

sections.heading: 2.3 Nano-reinforced laminates and prepreg process
sections.text:
The aforementioned prepared carbon nano-reinforced mixtures were used for the impregnation of unidirectional fabrics with a view to produce pre-impregnated fabrics according to the manual prepreg technique. Neat epoxy was also used as matrix in order to obtain the reference materials properties. The fabric impregnation was carried out at room temperature conditions. The b staging was succeeded by keeping the prepreg for 48h at RT according to manufacturer instructions. Then, the prepregs were used for the production of unidirectional CFRP laminates. Each panel was composed of 14 unidirectional plies and a 13-µm thick PTFE film was placed in the middle plane of each plate to generate the starter crack, which is required according to ASTM D5528 standard in order to perform the fracture tests. The laminates were cured in an autoclave oven according to the manufacturer instructions at 120°C for 2h and
6 bars pressure. The step by step preparation of the nano-doped CFRPs is schematically presented in Figure 1. The final thickness of the laminate was measured at 2.67 ±0.30 mm. The fiber volume fraction (Vf)of composites was calculated at 55-58%. Quality control for all the manufactured composites was performed utilizing the C-Scan ultrasonic technique. The results showed satisfactory and acceptable quality without major defects (heterogeneities, porosity, thickness variations and delamination). The final polymerization was completed in autoclave following the recommended curing and pressure profile: 2 hours at 120oC and3bars pressure.

sections.heading: 2.4 Mode I and Mode II fracture tests
sections.text:
The resistance to interlaminar crack propagation of the produced composites was defined by performing two types of fracture toughness experiments on a hydraulic universal testing machine (Instron 8872). Five samples were tested for each type of material system and for each type of experiment. The opening Mode I interlaminar fracture toughness, GIC, was determined by using the double cantilever beam (DCB) method and was carried out in accordance with ASTM Standard, D5528. DCB specimens were cut with a length of 140 mm, width of 20 mm and an initial crack of 50 mm .The experiments were performed with a crosshead speed of 0.5mm/min. The Mode II interlaminar fracture toughness, GIIC, was measured by using the three-point end-notched flexure (3ENF) method in accordance with Airbus Standard, AITM 1.0006. The test specimens were 200 mm long and 25 mm wide. The distance between the supports, i.e. the span length was 100 mm. The cross-head rate was kept at 1.0 mm/min. Finally, the fracture surfaces
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT C. Kostagiannakopoulou, X. Tsilimigkra, G. Sotiriadis and V. Kostopoulos
of the tested specimens were studied by using a LEO SUPRA 35VP Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM).

sections.heading: 3.1 Mode I DCB tests
sections.text: Mode I fracture energy for each prepared CFRP either with neat or nano-modified matrix is summarized in Figure 2. It is clearly seen that the GIC values of nano-doped matrix CFRP composites are significantly higher than that of reference material. It was observed that the incorporation of MWCNTs into the matrix material of CFRPs caused higher improvement of GIC as it is compared against the CFRPs with matrix modified with GNPs with the same %wt. of carbon nano-particles. More precisely, it can be seen that the integration of 1%wt. MWCNTs achieved the highest increase of 36% in GIC. Also, the addition of 0.5%wt. GNPs provides an enhancement of 27% in GIC, while marginally higher enhancement (31%) achieved with the incorporation of MWCNTs into the matrix at the same %wt. content. Finally, it was concluded that further increase of the content of GNPs into the matrix of CFRP composites did not lead to further enhancement of GIC, as it was observed in the case of MWCNT modified CFRP composites. Regarding the hybrid concepts, the combination of 0.5%wt. GNPs and 1%wt. MWCNTs highlighted the highest GIC (45%) value increase in comparison with the reference material. Slightly lower (38%) was the improvement of GIC achieved for hybrid 1 (0.5%wt. GNPs and 0.5%wt. MWCNTs) composite. The hybrid concepts are compared not only to the neat epoxy material but also to the composites doped with equal amounts of individual GNPs or MWCNTs. Accordingly, hybrid 1 /composite caused the enhancement of 7% and 11% in Mode I fracture toughness compared to MWCNT/ and GNP/composites respectively, at corresponding filler contents. In addition, hybrid 2/composite increased 18 and 9% the GIC value compared to composites doped with individual fillers of the same filler contents (0.5%wt. GNPs and 1%wt. MWCNTs).

sections.heading: 3.2 Mode II ENF tests
sections.text:
The Mode II fracture toughness of the manufactured CFRPs is presented in Figure 3. Clearly all the samples with nano-fillers modified matrix showed significant improvement in Mode II (GIIC) fracture toughness compared to pristine epoxy samples. In this failure type, in contrast to Mode I results, the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
presence of GNPs exhibited the highest enhancement in interlaminar fracture toughness of final composites. Specifically, it can be seen in Figure 3 that the major enhancement (18%) in GIIC achieved in the case of 0.5%wt. GNP/composite. Also, as in the case of Mode I tests, the increasing content of GNPs decreased (11%) the Mode II fracture toughness of CFRP composites. On the other hand, the introduction of highest content of MWCNTs into the matrix caused a further improvement in Mode II fracture toughness compared to composites doped with 0.5%wt. MWCNTs. Specifically, the addition of 1%wt. MWCNTs into the epoxy matrix achieved an increase of 13% while only 5% improvement succeeded with the incorporation of MWCNTs in content of 0.5%wt. Furthermore, hybrid/composites achieved remarkable increases in Mode II fracture toughness. In particular, the dominant combination was that of 0.5%wt.GNPs and 1%wt. MWCNTs (Hybrid 2) which reached the highest increase in fracture toughness (25%) compared to the reference material. In addition, the development of Hybrid 1 concept led to a considerable fracture toughness increase up to 20%. By comparing against the nano-doped composites with individual fillers, hybrid 1/composite achieved increases 2% and 15% compared to GNP and MWCNT/composite, respectively. In the case of Hybrid 2 concept, the GIIC toughness enhanced 7%and 12% in relation to doped composites with individual GNPs and MWCNTs, respectively. Table 3presents the increase achieved in Mode I and II fracture toughness with the incorporation of various amounts of fillers into the matrix of CFRP composite. Taking into consideration the aforementioned results we can claim that both nano-species significantly increase the fracture toughness of CFRPs compared to the composite with unmodified epoxy matrix due to the additional toughening/energy dissipation mechanisms that introduce during the crack propagation. According to literature [8,11,28-29], in case of composites doped with CNTs, pull out of nanotubes, debonding and pinning of crack seems to contribute to the increase of their fracture energy. On the other hand, crack tip bifurcation upon its meeting with the nano-particles, separation between the graphitic layers and the shear failure of the matrix (due to the difference in height observed on fracture surfaces) are the extra failure mechanisms that have been observed in graphene-based composites [16,30]. It is obvious from Figures 2 and 3 that MWCNTs are more promising fillers for increasing Mode I fracture toughness while GNPs proved more appropriate toughening nano-inclusions in order to improve
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT C. Kostagiannakopoulou, X. Tsilimigkra, G. Sotiriadis and V. Kostopoulos
Mode II fracture toughness. This is probably due to the more efficient contribution of pull out mechanisms, offered from MWCNTs, in tensile loading type (Mode I) and to the more effective activation of extra toughening mechanisms (bifurcation/separation of layers),introducing from GNPs, in shear loading type (Mode II). The aforementioned mechanisms are presented in detail in the fractographic analysis in the following section. Finally, the degradation of fracture properties with the increasing content of GNPs can be attributed to a possible aggregation. According to literature [31], the main reasons behind agglomeration are the van der Waals forces developed between the nano-fillers and their large surface areas. Furthermore, the strong π-π interactions between GNP sheets contribute to the stacking of individual sheets. In this study, GNPs seem to be more susceptible to aggregation than MWCNTs in the highest content of 1%wt. A possible explanation is that GNPs are larger particles than MWCNTs. In particular, the diameter of GNPs is in micro-scale while the length of MWCNTs ranges in nano-scale. Thus, the chance of interaction between GNPs because of the above reasoning is increased. In addition, the experimental results showed that the development of hybrid concepts caused further improvement in fracture properties of MWCNT/GNP modified composites in comparison with reference material and doped composites with individual fillers at corresponding contents. According to literature [25,31], the factors that probably contribute to this fact are described in the following paragraph. After the dispersion of MWCNTs and GNPs into the matrix of CFRP composite, the flexible MWCNTs are attracted through Van de Waals forces by the high surfaces of GNPs. Thus, MWCNTs approach the area of GNPs and it is usually observed their pinning on the surfaces of GNPs or their penetration between the GNP sheets. This entanglement leads to the formation of 3D structures which possess larger surface area than individual fillers do. In consequence, the contact surface area between 3D hybrids and epoxy matrix increases, resulting in more effective connection of fillers with matrix. Additionally, the MWCNTs that are included in 3D structures, usually act as tentacles into the composite which can be better embedded in the polymer chain and result in a better interaction between fillers and matrix. The aforementioned factors possibly improved the interface between 3D structures and matrix resulting in a more efficient transfer loading among them when stress is applied. Finally, these 3D structures have the tendency to combine the aforementioned absorption mechanisms of participating fillers resulting in
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
further improvement of fracture properties. The next chapter is going to be very helpful in order to understand better the above analysis.

sections.heading: 3.3 Fractographic Analysis
sections.text:
Fracture surfaces of the tested specimens were investigated using Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with the purpose of studying the distribution of nano-fillers in the epoxy matrix and their mutual interaction. Also, it was used in order to confirm the additional toughening mechanisms of fillers that were responsible for the remarkable increase in both GIC and GIIC. The Figure 4 presents the main failure mechanisms that were observed in case of MWCNT/composites. The red arrows indicate the presence of pinning and pull out absorption mechanisms that were introduced in the composite with the incorporation of MWCNTs. Figure 5 shows the basic failure mechanisms that were observed in GNP/composites. Specifically, images 5(b) and 5(c) present the bifurcation and the pinning of the crack when it meets GNPs. Additionally, the corresponding SEM images 5(a) and 5(d) depict the pull out behavior of GNPs and the separation of graphene layers of GNPs which are the additional observed toughening mechanisms of these fillers. Figures 6(a) to 6(c) present the energy absorption mechanisms that were observed in fracture surfaces of the hybrid composites. Figure 6(a) depicts the presence of both fillers within the matrix material. MWCNTs are also observed attached to GNPs in Figure 6(b). Different types of failure mechanisms are detected on fracture surfaces which confirm the synergistic effect of MWCNTs/GNPs. More precisely Figure 6(c) presents the bifurcation of the crack upon its meeting with GNPs. It is observed that the presence of nano-fillers inhibited the crack propagation. Firstly, the crack was pinned to the nano-fillers and then was separated in both sides of them. The arrows indicate the crack branching, while the GNPs that caused the bifurcation were circled in the images. Additionally, 6(c) SEM image depicts the pull-out behavior of MWCNTs/GNPs that took place during the fracture process. The arrow at this figure indicates this pull-out toughening mechanism, which contributes to the increase of the composite fracture energy. It is conceivable that upon crack propagation the synergistic effect of MWCNTs and GNPs act in order to deflect its smooth path. GNPs primarily prevent as possible the growth of major cracks and MWCNTs resist the propagation of smaller ones [32]. Thus, under their incorporation, the interlaminar fracture energy of the composite laminate is enhanced.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT C. Kostagiannakopoulou, X. Tsilimigkra, G. Sotiriadis and V. Kostopoulos

sections.heading: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
The objective of this study was to investigate the interlaminar fracture toughness of matrix nano-doped CFRPs using two types of carbon nano-particles. Specifically GNPs or/and MWCNTs, were mixed in an epoxy resin system at different contents (0.5 & 1%wt.). Both nano-fillers, improved the interlaminar fracture toughness of the final composite compared to the reference material. MWCNTs are more promising for the enhancement of Mode I fracture toughness whereas GNPs proved more appropriate toughening nano-inclusions in Mode II fracture toughness. This is probably attributable to the more efficient contribution of pull out mechanisms, provided by MWCNTs, in tensile loading type (Mode I). In shear loading type (Mode II) the extra toughening mechanisms (bifurcation/separation of layers), introduced by GNPs led to higher fracture toughness values. The degradation of fracture properties with the increasing content of GNPs can be associated to particles aggregations due to the strong van der Waals forces that usually are developed between carbon particles. In addition to the aforementioned remarks, the most significant outcome of the present work resulted from the combination of both nano fillers proving the positive synergistic effect. More precisely, under Mode I loading conditions, GIC indicated the highest increase (45%) when 0.5%wt. GNPs and 1%wt. MWCNTs were incorporated into the epoxy matrix of CFRP composites. The same hybrid carbon nano-fillers combination reported to conclude the best GIIC value by increasing GIIC of 25% compared to the reference composite. The nano fillers synergistic effect resulted in the introduction of additional toughening mechanisms (pull out and crack bifurcation), which are responsible for the improved interlaminar fracture properties of matrix nano-modified CFRPs. It is worth mentioning that the studied cases with nano fillers individually did not report higher fracture toughness values than hybrids ones, at the respective %wt. filler contents. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
The authors gratefully acknowledge the support of the present work by the European Union (European Social Fund - ESF) and the Greek national funds executed by the Greek Secretariat for Research & Technology within the frame of bilateral cooperation between Greece and Germany under the activity with the acronym GRACE.
